title: How to Make a Cookie Taste Freshly Baked

steps.headline: Crumple a paper towel and run it under water.
Squeeze and wring your towel until it is lightly damp.
steps.description: Don't make the towel too wet. The cookie may get soggy.

steps.headline: Wrap your cookie in the paper towel.
steps.description: For several cookies lay a moister towel over the plate.

steps.headline: Enjoy a cookie that tastes a whole lot fresher than before.
Slip a slice of fresh bread into the storage jar or container.
steps.description: Place it right on the cookies.

steps.headline: Leave the bread there.
steps.description: It will leach out the moisture into the cookies. This will restore the freshness to the cookies.

steps.headline: Eat quickly still.
steps.description: The bread trick won't last for more than 24-48 hours and if you leave it too long, the whole lot will go moldy.

steps.headline: Arrange the stale cookie or cookies upside down on a cookie sheet.
steps.description: It's going to be an easier clean-up for you if you line the sheet with parchment or baking paper first.

steps.headline: Drizzle syrup or honey over the base of each cookie.
Let the cookies sit for at least 10 minutes to soak in the sweet goodness.
steps.description: The syrup or honey will add a touch of moisture and a lot of flavor.

steps.headline: Eat soon.
steps.description: This solution is best done prior to serving and polishing off these almost stale cookies.
